importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was updated on this date, indicating ongoing developments in VA mental health policy and veteran concerns regarding therapy limitations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The policy shift to limit therapy sessions began around 2021 and intensified after President Donald Trump took office in January 2021 with Doug Collins as VA secretary, leading to widespread provider and veteran concerns.

keyTakeAways: VA therapy sessions for veterans are being limited under a policy enforced since 2021, particularly after Doug Collins became VA Secretary in January 2021.

Patients with chronic conditions like PTSD or depression may need long-term therapy, but VA policies now require a fixed number of sessions (4–24), with providers now pressured to terminate care early.
Providers report facing disciplinary consequences for challenging the policy, including loss of privileges and mandatory written justifications for extending sessions.
Veterans describe feeling abandoned and re-traumatized when forced to end therapy prematurely, especially when they are not ready to transition to alternative care like group therapy.
The American Psychological Association has acknowledged reports and is investigating, emphasizing that individualized, shared-decision care is essential for veteran recovery.

Some veterans, like Michael and Jake Pannell, have long-standing needs and express fear that mental health care is being treated as a short-term, crisis-driven model instead of a lifelong recovery process.
VA officials deny limiting appointments, claiming care is collaborative and tailored to patient needs, but providers and patients say implementation is inconsistent and clinically inappropriate.

namedEntities.name: Michael
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A combat veteran with PTSD who relies on one-on-one therapy and expresses alarm over its sudden termination.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Michael represents the emotional and psychological impact of therapy cuts on veterans who have built deep trust with their therapists and need long-term care.

namedEntities.name: Jake Pannell
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Army veteran with PTSD and anxiety, receiving long-term therapy at a VA facility in Washington state.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Jake exemplifies how veterans with chronic mental health conditions are being denied continued care, leading to fear of crisis and lack of stability.

namedEntities.name: Doug Collins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: VA Secretary appointed by President Donald Trump in January 2021, responsible for implementing policies affecting VA mental health care.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Collins’ leadership marked a shift in VA policy toward limiting therapy sessions, prompting widespread criticism from providers and veterans.

namedEntities.name: Peter Kasperowicz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: VA spokesperson who denies claims of therapy limits, stating that care is individualized and patient-driven.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kasperowicz represents the official VA position, which contradicts provider and veteran accounts, highlighting a conflict between policy enforcement and clinical need.

namedEntities.name: Stephen Long
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former VA psychologist at Northport VA Medical Center who retired in 2024 due to pressure to limit therapy sessions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Long’s resignation illustrates how policy pressure has led to staff attrition, worsening the VA’s already critical mental health workforce shortage.

namedEntities.name: Mark Jorges
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former psychotherapist and mental health counselor at a VA facility in Temple, Texas, who resigned in May 2024 due to therapy session limits.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Jorges’ departure underscores the frustration among mental health providers when clinical appropriateness is ignored in favor of rigid session limits.

namedEntities.name: American Psychological Association (APA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The largest professional organization for psychologists in the U.S., which is reviewing reports of therapy limitations in VA mental health care.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The APA’s involvement signals external validation of concerns and adds credibility to claims of inappropriate, non-clinically justified session limits.

namedEntities.name: VA (Department of Veterans Affairs)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The federal agency responsible for providing healthcare to veterans, including mental health services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The VA is at the center of the controversy, with conflicting statements between its leadership and frontline providers and patients about therapy access and care quality.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Veterans, including combat veterans Michael and Jake Pannell, are raising alarms over the VA’s recent policy of limiting one-on-one therapy sessions, which was intensified under VA Secretary Doug Collins starting in early 2021. While the VA claims care is patient-centered and collaborative, mental health providers report being pressured to terminate therapy prematurely, even for patients with chronic conditions like PTSD. Providers face disciplinary actions for challenging these limits, and some have resigned out of frustration. Veterans express feelings of abandonment and re-traumatization, citing a lack of trust and continuity in care. The American Psychological Association has acknowledged reports and is investigating. Critics argue that short-term, fixed-session models are clinically inappropriate for many veterans, especially those with long-term mental health needs, and that such policies undermine recovery and trust. The VA denies any systemic limits on appointments, but providers and patients say implementation is inconsistent and harmful.
title: VA Therapy Sessions Being Limited, Veterans and Providers Say
